parts.title: I
parts.markdown:
# Biology of Love
Meanings

1. When you work hard all month, and your employer refuses to pay you at the end of the month, saying, you did no work, will you sense that you are being cheated?
2. When you do not work all month and receive no reward at the end of the month, will you sense that you are being cheated?
3. Do you draw the same *meaning* from the different ways you are treated?
4. Give examples of different ways you can be treated and the meanings you may draw from them.
5. Can different people draw different meanings from the *same* treatment?
6. Give examples of how people may draw different meanings from the *same* treatment.
7. If you came across a poor person and offered them money, what possible meanings can they draw from it?
8. Is it possible for them to perceive it as a trick, that you will probably want something in return later on?
9. Is it possible for them to perceive it as showing off to everyone that you have money?
10. Is it possible for them to perceive it as you thinking that you can solve everyone's problem?
11. Is it possible for them to perceive it also as an act of love?
12. If you shared candies with a little child, would the child most likely perceive the treatment as love?
13. Will they still perceive the treatment as love if you kept sharing candies with this child until eventually, they lose all their teeth?
14. When they grow up and realize that they no longer have a perfect set of teeth, they cannot bite into most meals, and people are laughing at them, and you are the one to blame for it, will they continue to perceive your treatment as love?
15. Is love a form of meaning drawn from a treatment from another person?
16. Can a treatment that one person perceives as love, be perceived as another thing by another person?
17. When you come across your child disrespecting an elderly person and you drag them into the house and scold them, what meaning will the child draw from your actions?
18. Will the child perceive that you probably do not love them?
19. When the child grows up to discover the benefit of treating adults with respect after your scolding has straightened them, how will they perceive your scolding?
20. Will the child continue to perceive your treatment as hatred now that they are older?
21. How will they perceive your scolding now that they are older and have started reaping the benefits of respecting adults?
22.  What are some treatments that are always perceived as love, no matter who is receiving it?

parts.title: II
parts.markdown:
# Biology of Love II
Understanding

1. If love is a form of meaning drawn from how we are treated, then when given a set of individuals of various ages and backgrounds, how will you be able to identify the treatment that they will each sense as love?
2. Can you show love to an individual without first attempting to understand them?
3. What are some things that we should try to understand about others before we attempt to show love to them?
4. In what ways can you try to understand an individual?
5. How does *observing* people help us to understand them?
6. Give examples of things that we can observe about others.
7. How does *praying* for others help you to understand them?
8. Give examples of things that we can learn about others when we pray for them.
9. How does *actually* listening* to others when they are talking to us, help us to understand them?
10. Give examples of things that we can learn about others when we actually listen to them.
11. When attempting to understand adults, should we ask questions about their private lives, or wait for them to share them with us, willfully?
12. What could go wrong when we ask questions about other adults' private lives and do not wait for them to share them with us willfully?
13. When attempting to understand children, should we ask questions about their private lives, or give them their privacy?
14. What could go wrong when we give children their privacy?

Can you show love to an individual without first attempting to understand them?
What are some things that we should try to understand about others before we attempt to show love to them?
In what ways can you try to understand an individual?
How does *observing* people help us to understand them?
Give examples of things that we can observe about others.
How does *praying* for others help you to understand them?
Give examples of things that we can learn about others when we pray for them.
How does *actually* listening* to others when they are talking to us, help us to understand them?

When attempting to understand children, should we ask questions about their private lives, or give them their privacy?
What could go wrong when we give children their privacy?

parts.title: III
parts.markdown:
# Biology of Love III
Minister love, based on understanding

1. When you have understood the individual that you intend to minister love to, what is the final step?
2. Can you minister love to another person without sharing a piece of yourself with them? John 3:16
>For God so loved the world that he gave his one and only Son, that whoever believes in him shall not perish but have eternal life.
3. Did God so love the world that he said "I love you?"
4. Did God so love the world that he felt sad for the world?
5. Does God want you to love the whole world, in *words*, or one human a day, in *deed*?
6. What are some pieces of yourself that you can share with the people that you intend to love?
7. When you teach another person, do you lose what you have taught?
8. In what ways can you share your time with others?
9. In what ways can you share your money or the fruit of your hard work with others?
10. In what ways can you share your prayer with others?
11. When you pray for another person, are you sending God on an errand? 
12. In what ways does praying for another person enable God to minister his love to the person through you?
13. In what ways can you share compliments with others?
14. When you compliment others are you putting yourself above others, or pushing yourself to the background so that another person can also shine?
15. In what ways can you celebrate with others, knowing very well that you had rather be the one being celebrated?
16. In what ways can you share gifts with others?
17. In what ways can you minister love to other people, based on how you understand them?
18. In what ways can you minister love to a child?
19. In what ways can you minister love to a baby?
20. In what ways can you minister love to your parents?
21. In what ways can you minister love to your grandparents or the aged in your community?
22. In what ways can you minister love to your friends?
23. In what ways can you minister love to those who do not like you?
24. In what ways does praying for others, help you to find ways through which you can minister love to them?
25. Your baby brother and yourself, who needs more love from your parents?
26. What is the reason for your answer?
27. Your sick sister and your healthy mother, who needs more love from your father?
28. What is the reason for your answer?
29. The people who like you, and the people who do not like you, who need more love from you?
30. What is the reason for your answer?
31. Should you love everyone equally, or love as much as is needed by each individual?
32. What is the reason for your answer?
33. The people who like you and the people who do not like you, who should you show more love to?
34. What is the reason for your answer?
35. The people that are more difficult to love, and the people that are easy to love, who needs more love from you?
36. What is the reason for your answer? 
37. When you have helped in paying the school fees of another child, do you care if they fail their exams or not?
38. What is the reason for your answer?
39. Can you pray for someone every day, and wish ill upon them, at the same time?
40. Does sharing a piece of yourself with others make it easier for you to minister love to them?
41. What is the reason for your answer? 
42. In what way can you minister love to a person whom you simply don't like, and do not know why?
43. What is a rebuke?
44. When a person is going wayward and you do not rebuke them, do you love them?
45. In what ways can you rebuke a friend when they start going wayward?
46. Does God rebuke Man when they go wayward?
47. How did Christ rebuke pride in his disciples? Luke 9:46-48
>46 An argument started among the disciples as to which of them would be the greatest.  47 Jesus, knowing their thoughts,  took a little child and had him stand beside him.  48 Then he said to them,  “Whoever welcomes this little child in my name welcomes me; and whoever welcomes me welcomes the one who sent me.  For it is the one who is least among you all who is the greatest.”
48. How did Christ rebuke the sellers at the temple? Matthew 21:12-13
>12 Jesus entered the temple courts and drove out all who were buying and selling there. He overturned the tables of the money changers  and the benches of those selling doves.  13 “It is written,”  he said to them,  “‘My house will be called a house of prayer,’ but you are making it a den of robbers.”
49. Get a book and name it your "Love Book". In it, every day, write down how you ministered love to one individual, following the steps outlined:
	1. Understanding:  What did you do to understand them and what did you understand about them?
	3. Ministered love: How did you minister love to them, through understanding?
	4. Outcome: Were your actions interpreted as love? What challenges did you face, and how did you overcome them? What could you have done better?

parts.title: IV
parts.markdown:
# Biology of Love IV
Minister love, when understanding has completed its work

1. Read the story and recite it the way you remember it:
> When I was a kid, my mom often took me along on her trips. We spent a lot of time together, and she would buy me many gifts. But something odd always happened when we got back home. After getting off the bus, we would often meet one of my aunts. This aunt liked to talk a lot and would stop my mom for a long chat. She talked about her problems at home, church, school, and other random stuff. My aunt did most of the talking while my mom, who seemed to forget I was there, just listened and added a few words now and then. I would get bored, tired of waiting, and walk the rest of the way home by myself.
>
> One day, when I was a bit older, I asked my mom why she always ignored me and talked with my aunt for so long when we came back from our trips. She smiled and explained something surprising. My mom told me that my aunt was married to a man who never talked to her. She kept a lot of things inside and only felt better when she talked to my mom. My mom wanted to show her love by giving my aunt all her attention and listening to her, no matter where they met – at church, on the road, or at home.
>
>Hearing this, I felt sorry for getting angry and walking away from them. I understood my aunt better and decided to visit her regularly and listen to all her stories, even if they seemed boring to me.
2. What did your mum understand about your Aunt, and why she was such talkative?
3. Did your mum understand your Aunt by asking questions about your Aunt's private life, or did your Aunt most likely bring it up in one of her lengthy conversations?
4. By what means did your mum minister love to your Aunt?
5. Can giving someone a listening ear, be interpreted as love?

parts.title: V
parts.markdown:
# Biology of Love V
The Divine Technique

1. In what ways can a woman love by sharing a piece of themselves with another person, that a man cannot?
2. Are you willing to share your body with another human, allow another human to live inside your body for a couple of months, change your body and your habits, and cause you great discomfort or possibly even lose your life?
3. What is the divine technique for ministering love?
4. Is the divine technique available to women only, men only, or both?
5. Is it God's nature to share everything that he has including himself?
6. Do we live in God? Acts 17:28
> For in him we live and move and have our being.’ As some of your own poets have said, ‘We are his offspring.’
7. In what way does the divine technique, enable a woman to imitate the very nature of God?
8. Can the spiritual value that a woman gets from using the divine technique be compared to the deformity that it causes to their flesh, shape, or form?
9. Who created all humans and brought them into existence?
10. Do all humans love God in return?
11. Does bringing a child into the world, *automatically* mean that your child will love you in return?
12. Can your child grow up to hate you and even blame you for their failure in life?
13. Can your child do some of the most hurtful things to you?
14. When they do, should you give up on them, or forgive and continue to minister love to them?
15. In what ways can your love for your child, change them and put them on the right track?
16. What is the first thing that you must do when you bring a child into the world?
17. When you are not able to win your child over to yourself, with love, can you succeed in grooming them and delivering them to their destination?
18. Does God also work to win over his children, when he brings them into being?  
19. In what ways does God work to win over humans, once they are brought into the world, with love?
20. In what ways can you win your child over, with love, so that you can successfully groom them, before delivering them to their destination?
21. Exercise:
	1. Go to your mother
	2. Find out from them their experience while pregnant with you
	3. Actually listen to what they have to say and note everything down
	4. Gather and share with the rest of the class
22. Has your mother loved you in deed or in words?

parts.title: VI
parts.markdown:
# Biology of Love VI
Gravity of Love

1. In what ways has God ministered his love for humans?
2. Where does the spirit of the Father, in Man, come from?
3. In what way does the Father minister his love for humans through the divine technique?
4. Who created all the different energy sources that humans use daily?
5. Who put gold and oil in the ground, and for whom?
6. Can a human eat all the different types of foods that God has provided, in a lifetime?
7. Is the love of God all around us?
8. In what way can Man minister love to God, and God will interpret it as love? John 14:15
>“If you love me, obey my commandments.
9. Do you minister your love for God by telling him "I love you?"
10. Who created humans?
11. Is God human?
12. Does God know what it is like to be human?
13. In what way did Christ obtain his human experience?
14. Why is Christ called Son of Man and Son of God, after obtaining his human experience on earth?
15. In what ways does Christ minister his love for humans? John 14:14, John 14:16-17, John 16:13
>John 14:14
You may ask me for anything in my name, and I will do it.
>
>John 14:16-17
And I will ask the Father, and he will give you another Helper, to be with you forever, even the Spirit of truth, whom the world cannot receive, because it neither sees him nor knows him. You know him, for he dwells with you and will be in you.
>
>John 16:13
But when he, the Spirit of truth, comes, he will guide you into all the truth. He will not speak on his own; he will speak only what he hears, and he will tell you what is yet to come.
16. The Father and the Son, who is love? John 3:16
> 16 For God so loved the world, that he gave his only begotten Son, that whosoever believeth in him should not perish, but have everlasting life.
17. The Father and the Son, who is love in action?
18. Does the Father minister his love for humans directly, or through the Son?
19. Why does the Father minister his love for humans through the Son? John 5:26-27
> 26 For as the Father has life in himself, so he has granted the Son also to have life in himself.  27 And he has given him authority to judge because he is the Son of Man.
20. Write down a hundred(100) ways you can see the love of God all around you.

parts.title: VII
parts.markdown:
# Biology of Love VII
Gravity of Love

1. When you share a gift with your neighbor and experience the joy of sharing, are you more likely to share even more next time?
2. Does love grow?
3. Where do you sow the seed of love?
4. How do you make your love grow?
5. When you teach an individual, for free, is the individual also more likely to teach others for free?
6. Can someone who does not love, on receiving love from you, consider showing love for others?
7. Does love spread?
8. When you wear a smile and wave at a child, how is the child most likely to respond?
9. How do you make your love spread, even to the ends of the earth?
10. When you have a neighbor who does not like you, and you minister love to them, are they likely to change their mind about you, and even change their attitude towards you?
11. On learning that Christ was willing to live amongst men in order to teach them the ways of the Father, knowing that he will suffer horrible things and lose his own life, do you intend to live his message and be changed by it, or rather, reject it?
12. Does love change the individual receiving the love?
13. In what ways can love change the individual?
14. In what ways can love change even the most unrepentant sinner?
15. When you minister love to a wayward child, and your love never falters, is the child likely to reach a point in their lives where they begin to consider how their actions will affect you, and most likely make the right choices in order not to disappoint you?
16. Would you like to disappoint your parents after all the love they have ministered to you?
17. Would you like to disappoint your teachers after all that they have taught you?
18. Would you like to disappoint the Father after all the love he has ministered to you?
19. Does love serve as a guide and make us follow the right path?
20. In what ways can love guide an individual, and help them to walk the right path?
21. When you have given an individual a piece of yourself, does your word carry more weight with that individual, and makes them more likely to do what you tell them to do?
22. Should we use love to help each other to grow, or rather, influence others to do the wrong things?

sections.question: When you share a gift with your neighbor and experience the joy of sharing, are you more likely to share even more next time?
Does love grow?
Where do you sow the seed of love?
How do you make your love grow?
When you teach an individual, for free, is the individual also more likely to teach others for free?
Can someone who does not love, on receiving love from you, consider showing love for others?
Does love spread?
When you wear a smile and wave at a child, how is the child most likely to respond?
How do you make your love spread, even to the ends of the earth?
When you have a neighbor who does not like you, and you minister love to them, are they likely to change their mind about you, and even change their attitude towards you?

On learning that Christ was willing to live amongst men in order to teach them the ways of the Father, knowing that he will suffer horrible things and lose his own life, do you intend to live his message and be changed by it, or rather, reject it?
Does love change the individual receiving the love?
In what ways can love change the individual?
In what ways can love change even the most unrepentant sinner?

When you minister love to a wayward child, and your love never falters, is the child likely to reach a point in their lives where they begin to consider how their actions will affect you, and most likely make the right choices in order not to disappoint you?
Would you like to disappoint your parents after all the love they have ministered to you?
Would you like to disappoint your teachers after all that they have taught you?
Would you like to disappoint the Father after all the love he has ministered to you?
Does love serve as a guide and make us follow the right path?
In what ways can love guide an individual, and help them to walk the right path?
When you have given an individual a piece of yourself, does your word carry more weight with that individual, and makes them more likely to do what you tell them to do?
Should we use love to help each other to grow, or rather, influence others to do the wrong things?

parts.title: VIII
parts.markdown:
# Biology of Love VIII
Gravity of Love

1. Does the sun decide whom to shine upon?
2. Does the sun limit the extent of the reach of its light?
3. In what ways can we love like the sun?
4. Does the tree decide whom to provide shade for?
5. Does the tree decide whom to provide fruits for?
6. In what ways can we love like the tree?
7. Is the Father love?
8. Should his children also learn how to love, practice love, and become love?
9. What is the technique by which mortal man is able to become immortal?
10. Can God's children inherit immortality without imitating God by learning to love?
11. Do you have to be told to love before you start living?
12. Are you living when you do not love?

parts.title: I
parts.markdown:
# Character

1. Show me your muscle  
2. What does your muscle do for you? 
3. Can you carry all the heavy items around you with your muscles?  
4. If you wish to carry an object heavier than your muscles can handle, what must you do first?  
5. What exercises can you do to develop your muscles?
6. Will your muscles develop when you sleep all day and do nothing?
7. What would happen to you if you tried lifting a heavy object without first developing your muscles?
8. Do you know that your character is like a muscle?  
9. When you are not kind, can you share what you have with others?
10. If you wish to be kind, what will you have to do? 
11. When you are not patient, can you wait for a seed in the ground to grow up?
12. Will there be a time in your life when you will have to wait for something before it happens, no matter what you do?
13. If you misbehave while waiting are you patient?
14. If you remain calm and well-composed while waiting are you patient?
15. If you wish to be patient what will you have to do?
16. How do you develop your character?
17. A person who has been doing the right thing for two days, and a person who has been doing the right thing for one year, who is more righteous?
18. How do you strengthen your character?
19. What are some things that you do when helping a plant to grow or caring for a garden?
20. How does helping a plant to grow, or taking care of a garden help you to develop and strengthen your character?
21. What are some things that you do when caring for a pet?
22. How does raising a pet develop and strengthen your character?
23. How does cooking develop and strengthen your character?
24. How does repairing broken items, develop and strengthen your character?
25. How does taking instructions from your parents, and teachers, develop and strengthen your character?
26. Is the best time to develop character, when you are young, or when you are an adult?
27. What is the reason for your answer?
28. How can you tell if a person has developed their character?
29. Can a person look beautiful, yet have an ugly character?
30. What is the reason for your answer?
31. Can a person look ugly on the outside, yet beautiful on the inside?
32. What is the reason for your answer?
33. Can you tell the character of a person by their looks?
34. What is the reason for your answer?
35. What can go wrong when you try to tell a person's character by their look?
36. What is the character of a pig?
37. When can you say that a person has the character of a pig?
38. What is the character of a dog?
39. Does the dog return to it's vomit?
40. Do dogs have multiple sexual partners?
41. When can you say that a person has the character of a dog?
42. What is the character of a goat?
43. When can you say that a person has the character of a goat?
44. What is the character of a sheep?
45. When can you say that a person has the character of a sheep?
46. What is the character of a chicken?
47. What is animal fear?
48. When can you say that a person has the character of a chicken?
49. What is the character of the ant?
50. Does the ant need a leader to make them do the right thing?
51. Is the ant always on the lookout for opportunities?
52. When the ant finds an opportunity that is too big to handle alone, what does it do?
53. How does the ant behave when being blown by the wind?
54. What can you learn from the ant's behavior in the wind?
55. Does the ant spend all it has, today, or send most of it into the future to spend it when the need arises?
56. When can you say that a person has the character of an ant?
57. Does God fill every man's mind with good ideas?
58. Why do most people fail to bring their ideas to life?
59. Why do many marriages fail?
60. Can your marriage succeed when you have not developed your character?
61. Why do many businesses fail?
62. Can your business succeed when you have not developed your character?
63. Why do many people with good intentions, end up doing the opposite when the opportunity presents itself?
64. Why do many sons of God fail to live the Eternal Life?
65. When you are lazy, can you wake up early in the morning and pray?
66. Can you do the will of God when you have not developed your character?
67. Exercise:
		1. Take a plastic spoon 
		2. Fetch a spoonful of water from a bowl with the spoon 
		3. Hold it steady and walk a hundred meters away and back without losing half a spoon of the water
68. From the exercise above, describe your character.
69. From the exercise above, what can you do to develop and strengthen your character?
70. When your character has been developed, can anyone take it away from you?
71. What activities can you start doing to develop your character?
72. Character Activities:
	 - Split a group of young unstable individuals from stable individuals. Stable individuals learn a lesson. Stable individuals later split unstable individuals among themselves and teach them the lessons they have learned.
	 - Seal a bottle with super glue. Cut across the cover with a sharp knife, enough to slide a coin through. Save a coin in it each day. At the end of the week cut it open and give the money to a poor person around you.
	 - Grow a vegetable or crop that matures quickly, using plastic bottles with cutouts. These may include beans, okra, tomatoes, pepper, garden eggs, etc.
	 - Grow a crop that takes a little longer to mature in a garden. These may include yam, corn, potatoes, etc.
	 - Grow flowers in a plastic bottle with cutouts. 
	 - Plant a garden with all kinds of crops. Surround the garden with a fence.
	 - Take instructions from your mother or father, to prepare a meal. You will not be assisted in any other way. You will do this once a week for a month.
	 - Repair a broken item with supervision from an adult.
	 - Walk a distance without making a sound with your feet
	 - Say something nice to three people that you know each day
	 - Say something nice to a stranger each day 
	 - Mold an object with clay
	 - Say a prayer for someone other than yourself each day 
	 - Make a new friend
	 - Each day, correct someone who is doing something wrong
	 - Write a Thank You letter to your teachers
	 - Write a Thank You letter to your parents
	 - When you are sent on an errand to buy something, on your return give an account of the price of the item and the reason for the change
	 - Visit children at the hospital and pray for them, teach them to color, and help them memorize bible verses.
	 - Say sorry to a person you have offended
	 - Practice saying "Thank you!" two(2) times; first when you receive a gift or help, and second the day after, when you wake up first thing in the morning.
73. In what ways do these activities develop and strengthen your character?

parts.title: II
parts.markdown:
# Character II

1. What does it mean to have **Self Control**?
2. If you were doing your homework, and your mother told you that the food was ready, would you leave your homework to go and eat, or you will finish your homework, before going to eat?
3. If you left your homework to go and eat, do you have self-control?
4. If you finish your homework before going to eat, do you have self-control?
5. What will a person who has self-control do when:
	- He comes back home to find that the food in the house is only enough for one person, and he is in the house with his little sister.
	- He is learning in class and his friends want him to go outside and play with them.  
	- They are showing his favorite show on TV and he has homework to do.
	- He is all alone, and bad thoughts cross his mind.
6. Should we control our thoughts or let our thoughts control us?
7. In what other ways can you practice self-control?
8. What does it mean to be **Humble**?
9. How will you react When you are asked to learn how to read from a little child much younger than yourself because the child can read better than you?  
10. If you allowed yourself to be taught by the child, are you humble?
11. If you refuse to be taught by the little child, are you humble?
12. Can an adult learn something from a child without humility?  
13. When the adult refuses to be taught by the child, do they become wiser and better?
14. Do you become wiser and better, just because you are growing older?
15. Who is closer to the ground, the tall or the short person?
16. When a tall and short person is about to step into a trap, who is mostly to spot it first?
17. Why does pride come before a fall?
18. Can pride make you blind to the obvious? 
19. Can a person who has nothing, and does not know anything practice humility?  
20. Can God come to dwell amongst humans, and go through human suffering, without humility?
21. Is God humble? 
22. Should you be humble?
23. In what ways can you practice humility?
24. What does it mean to be **Respectable**?
25. What does it mean to be **Respectful**?  
26. How can you show respect for others?  
27. What does it mean to be respectable?  
28. What is the difference between being respectful and being respectable?  
29. What do you have to do to become respectable?  
30. Why must we be respectful?
31. Can you learn from your teacher when you do not respect them?
32. Why must we be respectable?
33. Will you gain favor from others when you are not respectable?
34. What is **Dignity** or **Self-respect**?
35. When do you say that a person has dignity?
36. Will you eat food that has been served on the floor?
37. When you do, do you have dignity?
38. Will you collect money from someone when they throw it on the flow?
39. When you do, do you have dignity?
40. What do you lose in character when you wear torn or dirty clothes?
41. What do you lose in character when you wear clothes that expose your body, especially parts of your body that are meant to be private?
42. In what ways can you grow in dignity?
43. What does it mean to **Obey** or be **Obedient**?
44. In what ways can you be obedient to your parents?
45. In what ways can you be obedient to God?
46. Can you obey God whom you cannot see when you do not obey your parents whom you can see?
47. Can you obey God whom you cannot see when you do not obey your teachers whom you can see?
48. Can you obey God whom you cannot see when you do not obey the elders in your community, whom you can see?
49. Why must you be obedient to those who are above you and watch over you?
50. Can you learn from your teacher when you are not willing to obey them?  
51. Can your parents protect you from danger when you are not willing to obey them?
52. Can God change you and polish you when you are not willing to obey his instructions?
53. Which one is more flexible, and can easily take a new shape, water or stone?
54. When your heart is as hard as stone in obedience, can God change you into something good and beautiful?
55. Should you be as flexible as water or as hard as stone in obedience?
56. Look around you and name a few things that are wrong in your environment because of disobedience.
57. In Numbers ‪20:8–11‬, how did Moses disobey God?
> 8 “Take the staff,  and you and your brother Aaron gather the assembly together. Speak to that rock before their eyes and it will pour out its water.  You will bring water out of the rock for the community so they and their livestock can drink.”
>
> 9 So Moses took the staff from the  Lord’s presence,  just as he commanded him.  10 He and Aaron gathered the assembly together in front of the rock and Moses said to them, “Listen, you rebels, must we bring you water out of this rock?”  11 Then Moses raised his arm and struck the rock twice with his staff. Water gushed out, and the community and their livestock drank.
58. In what way did Moses disobey God?
59. What was wrong with Moses' disobedience?
60. What does it mean to be **Accountable**?
61. When you are sent on an errand to buy an item, on your return do you just hand over the item and the change or do you hand over the item, and give a breakdown of the cost of the item before handing over the change?
62. If you merely handed over the item and the change are you accountable?
63. If you handed over the item, and gave a breakdown of the cost before handing over the change, are you accountable?
64. Why should we be accountable?
65. If you are accountable to your parents will you be accountable to God?
66. What are some things that your parents have given to you that you will have to account for, and how?
67. What are some things that God has given to you that you will have to account for?
68. Each day when you return from school give an account of your work at school to your parents.

parts.title: III
parts.markdown:
# The Heritage

1. Read the story and recite it the way you remember it:
> I grew up in a small town with my parents, who were very successful businesspeople. When they retired, they gave me two houses, two pieces of land, and a lot of money as a gift.
> 
> Having all that money was great, but I quickly realized that if I kept
spending it carelessly, it would soon run out. Then, a new business opportunity came to town. They promised to double any money you invested in just two weeks. Many people were making a lot of money from it, and I thought this was my chance to stay rich, or even get richer.
> 
> Remembering some of the wise things I had learned, I decided to invest a small amount first to see if it really worked. To my surprise, I got back double what I had invested. Excited, I invested more money and kept getting double the return. It seemed too good to be true.
> 
> Feeling confident, I sold my houses and land and invested everything into this business. But then, I discovered it was all a scam. They were just using new investors' money to pay off the old ones, and when they had collected enough, they ran away with all the money.
> 
> Now, I'm back living with my parents, just like when I started.
2. Why did I lose all that my parents had gifted me?
3. Which character made me lose everything?
4. Which character if present in me, would have stopped me from investing in the new business?
5. Did my parents indeed bless me when they gave me all their possessions?
6. Is character a better inheritance than material things?
7. What is the reason for your answer?

parts.title: IV
parts.markdown:
# The Little Girl and Her Bike

1. Read the story and recite it the way you remember it:
> One sunny day, I took my bike for a ride down a hill. There was a small bump on the road meant to slow down cars.
> 
> When I hit the bump, my bike flew up! The next thing I remember is waking up in the hospital. I was surrounded by a doctor, nurses, and a familiar face. I recognized him as the man who worked at an electronics store near where I was riding my bike.
> 
> He explained what had happened. After my bike hit the bump, I fell and fainted in the middle of the road. He remembered me because I always smiled and said hi whenever I passed by. He and his friend couldn't leave me there, so they quickly stopped a taxi and took me to the hospital.
2. What could have happened to you if you were left alone in the middle of the road?
3. Why did the man rush to your rescue when you fainted?
4. Was it your character that saved you, or you were saved because of your beauty?
5. What would have happened to you if the people who saw what happened, wished to help, but hesitated because you were a rich man's child, and would be accused of trying to steal from you?
6. While you were lying in the middle of the road, was it the money in your pocket that came out of your pocket, hailed a taxi, and took you to the hospital?
7. Was it your expensive bike, clothes, or phone that saved you?
8. Was it your parents that came to your rescue?
9. Who took you to the hospital?
10. Was it your rich parent's maid or personal assistants who found you and took you to the hospital?
11. Who saved you?
12. What would have happened to you when you fainted on the road if you had been rude to the people around you, or simply pretended that they did not exist anytime you passed by?
13. How should we treat the people around us?

parts.title: V
parts.markdown:
# The Textile Factory

1. Read the story and recite it the way you remember it:
> I was in charge of a factory that made lots of beautiful and strong fabrics. As long as we kept making good fabrics, people kept buying them. Every morning, my driver would take me to work in my fancy car. I would pass by all the workers and cleaners, watching them from behind my tinted windows because I didn’t want to talk to them about their problems. My relationship with them was just about business.
>
>From where I sat, everything seemed perfect. The factory was running well, and our business was great. We had many checks to make sure no one took anything they weren’t supposed to. Everything going in and out of the factory was tracked, except maybe the garbage truck. At the end of the day, my driver would pick me up, and I’d watch the workers from behind my tinted windows again. But then I noticed something strange; we were making lots of fabric, but our sales and profits were going down.
>
>One sad day, I had to make a tough decision to close the factory because we ran out of money. I had already sold my car, so I had to walk out and see the disappointed faces of the workers. An old lady who worked as a cleaner came up to me, and I thought she would ask for help for her family. Instead, she took me aside and shared a secret with me.
>
>Some workers had been sneaking large amounts of our beautiful fabrics out of the factory using the garbage trucks.
2. Which character made me not want to associate with the lesser people in my factory?
3. Which character could have helped me to save the factory from closing down?
4. How would you ensure that when God lifts you, you will remain up?

parts.title: I
parts.markdown:
# Compliments

1. What is a compliment?
2. Is it a compliment if it does not praise something good about the person?
3. What are some things that you can compliment about a person's appearance?
4. What are some things that you can compliment about a person's character?
5. What are some things that you can compliment about something that a person does?
6. How do you receive a compliment?
7. Is it a compliment if it is not honest?
8. Is it a compliment if it is not positive?
9. How will you compliment your mother?
10. Go and compliment your mother and come back.
11. How will you compliment your father?
12. Go and compliment your father and come back.
13. How will you compliment your friend? 
14. Pay a compliment to someone around you, about their appearance, character, and something that they have done.
15. How did they receive your compliment?
16. Were they happy?
17. Should we compliment others every day?

parts.title: II
parts.markdown:
# Compliments II

1. What is a compliment?
2. Why should we compliment others?
3. Draw a picture of a human body.
4. Draw a little circle on its chest.
5. Draw a straight line from the little circle out of the body and label it **friendly**.
6. Draw another little circle in the chest of the body.
7. Draw a straight line from the little circle out of the body and label it **disrespectful**.
8. Which circle do you wish to grow bigger? **friendly** circle or **disrespectful** circle?
9. How do you make the **friendly** circle grow bigger?
10. What do you have to do if you want the good in other people to grow?
11. What happens to a person when you compliment them about the good in them?
12. Will they continue to do more of the good when you compliment them about it?

parts.title: I
parts.markdown:
# Faith, Believe

1. Are you able to hear the voice of God? John 10:27-28
>27 My sheep hear my voice, and I know them, and they follow me:
28 And I give unto them eternal life; and they shall never perish, neither shall any man pluck them out of my hand.
2. Are you a goat or a sheep?
3. When do you say that you have **faith**?
4. Can you say you have faith when God has not spoken to you? 
5. When you have faith, will you doubt it?
6. When you are not sure if you heard from God, is it faith?
7. Is faith a feeling?
8. Will God tell you to do something big when you have not done the little thing he has asked you to do?
9. Will God give you big faith when you have not acted on the little faith that he has given you?
10. Can your faith grow?
11. How do you make your faith grow?
12. Give an example of how you can make your faith grow
13. Do you wish to hear God's voice?
14. Pray to God to give you a hearing heart.
15. When do you say that you **believe** something?
16. When you receive faith and act on it, do you believe?
17. When you receive faith, and you do not act on it, do you believe?
18. Do you believe by your words or by your actions?
19. If you say that you believe, yet do not act on it, do you believe?
20. If you say that you do not believe, yet act on it, did you believe?
21. What is the story? Matthew 14:22-33
22. From the passage, where do you find faith?
23. Where do you find belief?
24. What would have happened if Peter tried walking on the water without first receiving a word from Christ?
25. If you believe in the word God has spoken to you, will anything be impossible to you? Matthew 17:20
> He replied, “Because you have so little faith. Truly I tell you, if you have faith as small as a mustard seed, you can say to this mountain, ‘Move from here to there,’ and it will move. Nothing will be impossible for you.”
26. What is the story of Jesus and the Rich Young Ruler? Matthew 19:16-22
> 16 Just then a man came up to Jesus and asked, “Teacher, what good thing must I do to get eternal life?”
> 
> 17 “Why do you ask me about what is good?”  Jesus replied.  “There is only One who is good. If you want to enter life, keep the commandments.”
> 
> 18 “Which ones?” he inquired.
> 
> Jesus replied,  “‘You shall not murder, you shall not commit adultery, you shall not steal, you shall not give false testimony,  19 honor your father and mother,’ and ‘love your neighbor as yourself.’”
> 
> 20 “All these I have kept,” the young man said. “What do I still lack?”
> 
> 21 Jesus answered,  “If you want to be perfect,  go, sell your possessions and give to the poor,  and you will have treasure in heaven.  Then come, follow me.”
> 
> 22 When the young man heard this, he went away sad, because he had great wealth.
27. From the passage, where do you find faith?
28. Did the Rich Young Ruler believe?
29. What is the reason for your answer?
30. Did Jesus ask the Rich Young Ruler to say "I believe that you are the son of God?"
31. Did Jesus ask the Rich Young Ruler to give all his riches to him?
32. What is the story? John 11:19-44
33. From the passage, where do you find faith?
34. In verse 27, did Martha believe?
35. In verses 39-40, did Martha believe?
36. When did they believe?
37. Can you believe in God and not do what God tells you to do?
38. How do you believe in John 3:16?
> For God so loved the world that he gave his one and only Son, that whoever believes in him shall not perish but have eternal life.
39. Is there greatness in every man?
40. Why is there greatness in every man?
41. Why are some people great, and others are not? 
42. Quiet Time. Each morning, you wake up earlier than you usually do and do a few things:
	- Sing a worship song to God. Singing worship songs has a way of transforming you from the inside, making you spiritually sensitive, and allowing you to feel God's presence in you.
	-  You say a prayer
	- Read a portion of scripture, vocally. You can start with the gospels (Matthew, Mark, Luke, John) before reading Proverbs, Psalms, and the others.
	-  Meditate on what you have read and think about ways in which you can apply it. For instance, if Christ said that we shall be judged by every single word that we speak, I will start by repenting from every foul word I have ever spoken and be determined to speak only good words from now on.
	- God will begin to speak with you. Do as he says.
	- God loves consistency
43. Should the child of God attempt to live by every word from God? Matthew 4:4
> Matthew 4:4
> 4 Jesus answered, “It is written: ‘Man shall not live on bread alone, but on every word that comes from the mouth of God.’”
>
>Deuteronomy 8:3
>3 So He humbled you, allowed you to hunger, and fed you with manna which you did not know nor did your fathers know, that He might make you know that man shall not live by bread alone; but man lives by every _word_ that proceeds from the mouth of the Lord.
44. Should the child of God attempt to live by every word from God, both written and unwritten?
45. Have you received a word from God in the past?
46. If yes then what are you waiting for?

parts.title: II
parts.markdown:
# Faith, Believe II

1. When do you say that you have faith in someone?
2. When do you say that you have faith in God? Matthew 8:5-10
> 5 When Jesus had entered Capernaum, a centurion came to him, asking for help.  6 “Lord,” he said, “my servant lies at home paralyzed,  suffering terribly.”
>
>7 Jesus said to him,  “Shall I come and heal him?”
>
>8 The centurion replied, “Lord, I do not deserve to have you come under my roof. But just say the word, and my servant will be healed.  9 For I myself am a man under authority, with soldiers under me. I tell this one, ‘Go,’ and he goes; and that one, ‘Come,’ and he comes. I say to my servant, ‘Do this,’ and he does it.”
>
>10 When Jesus heard this, he was amazed and said to those following him,  “Truly I tell you, I have not found anyone in Israel with such great faith.
3. Did the centurion believe quietly or vocally?
4. How did the woman with the issue of bleeding receive healing from God through her faith? Matthew 9:20-22
> 20 Just then a woman who had been subject to bleeding for twelve years came up behind him and touched the edge of his cloak.  21 She said to herself, “If I only touch his cloak, I will be healed.”
>
>22 Jesus turned and saw her.  “Take heart,  daughter,”  he said,  “your faith has healed you.”  And the woman was healed at that moment.
5. Did she believe quietly, or vocally?
6. How did the blind receive their sight by exercising their faith? Matthew 9:28-30
> 28 When he had gone indoors, the blind men came to him, and he asked them,  “Do you believe that I am able to do this?”
>
>“Yes, Lord,” they replied.
>
>29 Then he touched their eyes and said,  “According to your faith let it be done to you”;  30 and their sight was restored. Jesus warned them sternly,  “See that no one knows about this.”
7. When you believe in your heart that God can do something and you say it aloud, will God do it if it's part of His plan? Matthew 8:13
> 13 Then Jesus said to the centurion, “Go! Let it be done just as you believed it would.” And his servant was healed at that moment.
8. If you say out loud, "Heavenly Father, I believe you can make me completely healthy right now," and deep down you really believe it without any doubt, do you think He will make you healthy again?
9. If you say out loud, "Heavenly Father, I believe you can restore peace to my family," and deep down you really believe it without any doubt, do you think He will restore peace to your family?
10. If you say out loud, "Heavenly Father, I believe you can make all good things abound towards me," and deep down you really believe it without any doubt, do you think He will make all good things abound towards you?
11. If your *mouth* says it and your *heart* agrees with it, will you have what you ask?
12. How do you receive salvation by exercising your faith? Romans 10:8-9
> 8 But what does it say?  “The word is near you, in your mouth and in your heart”  (that is, the word of faith which we preach): 9 that  if you confess with your mouth the Lord Jesus and believe in your heart that God has raised Him from the dead, you will be saved.
13. How do you receive protection from God by exercising your faith? Psalm 91:9-13
> 9 If you say, “The  Lord  is my refuge,”  
and you make the Most High your dwelling,  
10 no harm  will overtake you,  
no disaster will come near your tent.  
11 For he will command his angels  concerning you  
to guard you in all your ways;  
12 they will lift you up in their hands,  
so that you will not strike your foot against a stone.  
13 You will tread on the lion and the cobra;  
you will trample the great lion and the serpent.
14. Say out loud 10 things that you believe your Heavenly Father can do for you, that you do not doubt in your heart He is able to do.
15. >_“Heavenly Father, I believe that You are Jehovah Rapha, the Lord who heals me. I declare that by the stripes of Jesus, I am healed. Sickness has no power over my body. My health springs forth speedily, and I walk in divine strength and vitality, in Jesus' name.”_ (Isaiah 53:5, Exodus 15:26)
16. >_“Lord, Your Word says You forgive all my sins and heal all my diseases. I declare restoration to every part of my body. I reject every diagnosis that contradicts Your promise. Healing belongs to me as a covenant child, in Jesus’ name.”_ (Psalm 103:2–3, Matthew 8:17)
17. >_“Lord, I thank You that no weapon formed against me or my family shall prosper. I declare that we dwell in the secret place of the Most High and abide under the shadow of the Almighty. Your angels are assigned to guard us in all our ways, in Jesus' name.”_  (Psalm 91:1–11, Isaiah 54:17) 
18. >_“I declare that the Lord is my refuge and fortress. I will not fear evil, danger, or calamity. My family is shielded by the blood of Jesus. We are preserved from all harm, and we go out and return in peace.”_  (Proverbs 18:10, Psalm 121:7–8)
19. >_“Heavenly Father, I declare that Your peace, which surpasses all understanding, guards my heart and mind through Christ Jesus. I will not fear or be anxious, because You are with me. My home is filled with peace, joy, and Your perfect love.”_  (Philippians 4:6–7, Isaiah 26:3)
20. >_“I cast all my cares on You, Lord, because You care for me. I declare freedom from anxiety, depression, and fear. The joy of the Lord is my strength, and I live in emotional stability and mental wholeness.”_  (1 Peter 5:7, Nehemiah 8:10)
21. >_“Heavenly Father, You are my provider, and I shall not lack any good thing. I declare that all my needs are met according to Your riches in glory by Christ Jesus. My family walks in abundance and generosity because You bless the work of our hands.”_  (Psalm 23:1, Philippians 4:19, Deuteronomy 28:12)
22. >_“I declare that wealth and riches are in my house, and the blessing of the Lord makes rich and adds no sorrow. I am a faithful steward, and I sow generously and reap bountifully. Financial breakthroughs locate my family continually.”_ (Proverbs 10:22, Psalm 112:3, 2 Corinthians 9:6)
23.  >_“Lord, I declare that my children are taught of the Lord, and great is their peace. My household serves the Lord with joy. We walk in unity, love, and purpose. Every member of my family fulfills the divine destiny ordained by You.”_ (Isaiah 54:13, Joshua 24:15)
24. >_“I speak blessing over my family. Love, forgiveness, and grace reign in our home. Our relationships are strong, our hearts are united, and the presence of God is at the center of all we do.”_ (Psalm 133:1, Colossians 3:13–14)
25. >_“Heavenly Father, I trust You to direct my steps. I declare that I am led by Your Spirit and I walk in wisdom and discernment. You order my path and establish my plans as I commit all things into Your hands.”_ (Proverbs 3:5–6, Psalm 37:23)
26. >_“I declare that I have the mind of Christ. I know what to do, where to go, and how to move forward. My life is aligned with heaven’s purpose, and I will fulfill my assignment with clarity and confidence.”_ (1 Corinthians 2:16, Isaiah 30:21)
27. >_“God, I believe that You are at work in me, both to will and to do of Your good pleasure. I declare that I am growing in grace and in the knowledge of Jesus. My faith is strong, unwavering, and rooted in Your Word.”_ (Philippians 2:13, 2 Peter 3:18)
28. >_“I hunger and thirst for righteousness, and I am filled daily with Your Spirit. I declare that I walk in intimacy with You. I hear Your voice clearly, I obey joyfully, and I shine as a light in this world.”_ (Matthew 5:6, John 10:27, Philippians 2:15)
29. >"God, I may not always understand the path I’m on, but I trust that You’re walking it with me every step of the way."
30. >"Even when I feel alone or unseen, I believe You see me, know me, and care deeply about my life."
31. >"When things around me are uncertain, I anchor my heart in You, because You’ve never failed me before."
32. >"I believe You are working behind the scenes in ways I can’t see right now, and that gives me peace."
33. >"I trust that nothing I face today is too much for me, because I know You’ve already given me the grace to overcome it."
34. >"You are the quiet strength in me when I feel weak, and the calm voice I hear when my world feels noisy."
35. >"I believe You’ve planted dreams in my heart for a reason, and I won’t give up on them, because You haven’t."
36. >"I may not have it all figured out, but I know I’m not walking through life without purpose, because I’m walking with You."
37. >"When I’m overwhelmed, I remind myself that You’re not asking me to have all the answers—just to keep holding on."
38. >"My story may have had dark chapters, but I declare that the Author of my life is still writing something beautiful."

But just say the word, and my servant will be healed.  9 For I myself am a man under authority, with soldiers under me. I tell this one, ‘Go,’ and he goes; and that one, ‘Come,’ and he comes. I say to my servant, ‘Do this,’ and he does it.”
>
>10 When Jesus heard this, he was amazed and said to those following him,  “Truly I tell you, I have not found anyone in Israel with such great faith.

sections.question: Did the centurion believe quietly or vocally?
How did the woman with the issue of bleeding receive healing from God through her faith? Matthew 9:20-22
sections.body:
> 20 Just then a woman who had been subject to bleeding for twelve years came up behind him and touched the edge of his cloak.  21 She said to herself, “If I only touch his cloak, I will be healed.”
>
>22 Jesus turned and saw her.  “Take heart,  daughter,”  he said,  “your faith has healed you.”  And the woman was healed at that moment.

sections.question: Did she believe quietly, or vocally?
How did the blind receive their sight by exercising their faith? Matthew 9:28-30
sections.body:
> 28 When he had gone indoors, the blind men came to him, and he asked them,  “Do you believe that I am able to do this?”
>
>“Yes, Lord,” they replied.
>
>29 Then he touched their eyes and said,  “According to your faith let it be done to you”;  30 and their sight was restored. Jesus warned them sternly,  “See that no one knows about this.”

sections.question: When you believe in your heart that God can do something and you say it aloud, will God do it if it's part of His plan? Matthew 8:13
sections.body: > 13 Then Jesus said to the centurion, “Go! Let it be done just as you believed it would.” And his servant was healed at that moment.

sections.question: If you say out loud, "Heavenly Father, I believe you can make me completely healthy right now," and deep down you really believe it without any doubt, do you think He will make you healthy again?
If you say out loud, "Heavenly Father, I believe you can restore peace to my family," and deep down you really believe it without any doubt, do you think He will restore peace to your family?

If you say out loud, "Heavenly Father, I believe you can make all good things abound towards me," and deep down you really believe it without any doubt, do you think He will make all good things abound towards you?
If your *mouth* says it and your *heart* agrees with it, will you have what you ask?
How do you receive salvation by exercising your faith? Romans 10:8-9
sections.body: > 8 But what does it say?  “The word is near you, in your mouth and in your heart”  (that is, the word of faith which we preach): 9 that  if you confess with your mouth the Lord Jesus and believe in your heart that God has raised Him from the dead, you will be saved.

sections.question: How do you receive protection from God by exercising your faith? Psalm 91:9-13
sections.body:
> 9 If you say, “The  Lord  is my refuge,”  
and you make the Most High your dwelling,  
10 no harm  will overtake you,  
no disaster will come near your tent.  
11 For he will command his angels  concerning you  
to guard you in all your ways;  
12 they will lift you up in their hands,  
so that you will not strike your foot against a stone.  
13 You will tread on the lion and the cobra;  
you will trample the great lion and the serpent.

sections.question: Say out loud 10 things that you believe your Heavenly Father can do for you, that you do not doubt in your heart He is able to do.

>_“Heavenly Father, I believe that You are Jehovah Rapha, the Lord who heals me. I declare that by the stripes of Jesus, I am healed. Sickness has no power over my body. My health springs forth speedily, and I walk in divine strength and vitality, in Jesus' name.”_ (Isaiah 53:5, Exodus 15:26)

>_“Lord, Your Word says You forgive all my sins and heal all my diseases. I declare restoration to every part of my body. I reject every diagnosis that contradicts Your promise. Healing belongs to me as a covenant child, in Jesus’ name.”_ (Psalm 103:2–3, Matthew 8:17)

>_“Lord, I thank You that no weapon formed against me or my family shall prosper. I declare that we dwell in the secret place of the Most High and abide under the shadow of the Almighty. Your angels are assigned to guard us in all our ways, in Jesus' name.”_  (Psalm 91:1–11, Isaiah 54:17)

>_“I declare that the Lord is my refuge and fortress. I will not fear evil, danger, or calamity. My family is shielded by the blood of Jesus. We are preserved from all harm, and we go out and return in peace.”_  (Proverbs 18:10, Psalm 121:7–8)

>_“Heavenly Father, I declare that Your peace, which surpasses all understanding, guards my heart and mind through Christ Jesus. I will not fear or be anxious, because You are with me. My home is filled with peace, joy, and Your perfect love.”_  (Philippians 4:6–7, Isaiah 26:3)

>_“I cast all my cares on You, Lord, because You care for me. I declare freedom from anxiety, depression, and fear. The joy of the Lord is my strength, and I live in emotional stability and mental wholeness.”_  (1 Peter 5:7, Nehemiah 8:10)

>_“Heavenly Father, You are my provider, and I shall not lack any good thing. I declare that all my needs are met according to Your riches in glory by Christ Jesus. My family walks in abundance and generosity because You bless the work of our hands.”_  (Psalm 23:1, Philippians 4:19, Deuteronomy 28:12)

>_“I declare that wealth and riches are in my house, and the blessing of the Lord makes rich and adds no sorrow. I am a faithful steward, and I sow generously and reap bountifully. Financial breakthroughs locate my family continually.”_ (Proverbs 10:22, Psalm 112:3, 2 Corinthians 9:6)

>_“Lord, I declare that my children are taught of the Lord, and great is their peace. My household serves the Lord with joy. We walk in unity, love, and purpose. Every member of my family fulfills the divine destiny ordained by You.”_ (Isaiah 54:13, Joshua 24:15)

>_“I speak blessing over my family. Love, forgiveness, and grace reign in our home. Our relationships are strong, our hearts are united, and the presence of God is at the center of all we do.”_ (Psalm 133:1, Colossians 3:13–14)

>_“Heavenly Father, I trust You to direct my steps. I declare that I am led by Your Spirit and I walk in wisdom and discernment. You order my path and establish my plans as I commit all things into Your hands.”_ (Proverbs 3:5–6, Psalm 37:23)

>_“I declare that I have the mind of Christ. I know what to do, where to go, and how to move forward. My life is aligned with heaven’s purpose, and I will fulfill my assignment with clarity and confidence.”_ (1 Corinthians 2:16, Isaiah 30:21)

>_“God, I believe that You are at work in me, both to will and to do of Your good pleasure. I declare that I am growing in grace and in the knowledge of Jesus. My faith is strong, unwavering, and rooted in Your Word.”_ (Philippians 2:13, 2 Peter 3:18)

>_“I hunger and thirst for righteousness, and I am filled daily with Your Spirit. I declare that I walk in intimacy with You. I hear Your voice clearly, I obey joyfully, and I shine as a light in this world.”_ (Matthew 5:6, John 10:27, Philippians 2:15)
>"God, I may not always understand the path I’m on, but I trust that You’re walking it with me every step of the way."
>"Even when I feel alone or unseen, I believe You see me, know me, and care deeply about my life."
>"When things around me are uncertain, I anchor my heart in You, because You’ve never failed me before."
>"I believe You are working behind the scenes in ways I can’t see right now, and that gives me peace."
>"I trust that nothing I face today is too much for me, because I know You’ve already given me the grace to overcome it."
>"You are the quiet strength in me when I feel weak, and the calm voice I hear when my world feels noisy."
>"I believe You’ve planted dreams in my heart for a reason, and I won’t give up on them, because You haven’t."
>"I may not have it all figured out, but I know I’m not walking through life without purpose, because I’m walking with You."
>"When I’m overwhelmed, I remind myself that You’re not asking me to have all the answers—just to keep holding on."
>"My story may have had dark chapters, but I declare that the Author of my life is still writing something beautiful."

parts.title: I
parts.markdown:
# Forgive

1. When you have a problem with another human, will you choose the *problem* or the *human*?
2. If you choose the human, what will you have to do?
3. Read the following and use it to answer the following questions:
> I have a really good friend who always helps me with things that would be really hard to do on my own. One day, this friend does something that makes me really mad. I keep thinking about what I’ll say or do when I see them again. Now I have two choices: I can either keep the friendship we had or stay angry at them.
4. What will happen if you choose friendship?
5. Will you be able to continue working with them?
6. Will you have to avoid them, anytime you meet them?
7. What will happen if you choose your anger?
8. Will you be able to continue your friendship with them?
9. Will you have to avoid them, anytime you meet them?
10. What look would you have to wear on your face if you had to be in the same place with them?
11. Will you choose friendship or your anger?
12. If you chose friendship, what do you have to do in response to the offense?
13. Should your friend know that they have been forgiven?
14. What will happen if you forgive them but not let them know they have been forgiven?
15. How will you let your friend know that you have forgiven them?
16. Will your friends, parents, or even siblings one day offend you?
17. Why will they offend you no matter what?
18. Will you forgive them now or wait until after they first offended you and apologized?
19. Do you **fore**give be**fore** or after you have been offended?
20. What is the reason fro your answer?

sections.question: When you have a problem with another human, will you choose the *problem* or the *human*?
If you choose the human, what will you have to do?
Read the following and use it to answer the following questions:

I keep thinking about what I’ll say or do when I see them again. Now I have two choices: I can either keep the friendship we had or stay angry at them.

Will you have to avoid them, anytime you meet them?

Will you choose friendship or your anger?
If you chose friendship, what do you have to do in response to the offense?
Should your friend know that they have been forgiven?
What will happen if you forgive them but not let them know they have been forgiven?
How will you let your friend know that you have forgiven them?
Will your friends, parents, or even siblings one day offend you?
Why will they offend you no matter what?
Will you forgive them now or wait until after they first offended you and apologized?
Do you **fore**give be**fore** or after you have been offended?
What is the reason fro your answer?

parts.title: II
parts.markdown:
# Forgive II

1. After offending someone, what do you carry on your conscience?
2. What happens when you sprinkle water over hot oil on a fire?
3. What causes the guilt in your conscience after you have offended someone?
4. When you feel guilty, can you carry out your duties like before?
5. When you are forgiven, what happens to your guilt? Isaiah 6:1-7
> In the year that  King Uzziah died I  saw the Lord sitting upon a throne, high and lifted up; and the train of his robe filled the temple.  2 Above him stood the seraphim. Each had six wings: with two he covered his face, and with two he covered his feet, and with two he flew.  3 And one called to another and said:
> 
> “Holy, holy, holy is the  Lord  of hosts;   the whole earth is full of his glory!”
> 
> 4 And the foundations of the thresholds shook at the voice of him who called, and the house was filled with smoke.  5 And I said: “Woe is me!  For I am lost;  for I am a man of unclean lips, and I dwell in the midst of a people of unclean lips; for my eyes have seen the King, the  Lord  of hosts!”
> 
> 6 Then one of the seraphim flew to me, having in his hand a burning coal that he had taken with tongs from the altar.  7 And he  touched my mouth and said: “Behold, this has touched your lips; your guilt is taken away, and your sin atoned for.”
6. When you refuse to forgive someone, are you holding them prisoner in your heart? Isaiah 58:6
> “No, this is the kind of fasting I want: Free those who are wrongly imprisoned; lighten the burden of those who work for you. Let the oppressed go free, and remove the chains that bind people.
7. When you forgive them, have you broken the chains that bind them?
8. If you were about to start an adventure and someone told you that making even one mistake would be deadly, and you knew you weren't perfect and were bound to mess up, would you still go on the adventure?
9. Can you become perfect at something without a second or multiple attempts?
10. If you do not forgive the people who offend you, will they get another chance to do better? 
11. How does forgiving others help them to become perfect? 
12. When a person insults you for no reason at all, do you just stay silent and not mind them, or do you show them an act of love by saying "Thank you!" with a smile?
13. Who forgives best, the one who does nothing when they are offended, or the one who responds with kindness? Luke 23:33-34
> 33 When they came to the place called the Skull, they crucified him there, along with the criminals—one on his right, the other on his left.  34 Jesus said,  “Father,  forgive them, for they do not know what they are doing.” And they divided up his clothes by casting lots.
14. What did Jesus mean by turning the other cheek? Matthew 5:39
>39 But I tell you, do not resist an evil person. If anyone slaps you on the right cheek, turn to them the other cheek also.
15. Is forgiveness needed in Heaven?
16. What is the reason for your answer
17. Is there someone that you have not forgiven?
18. If yes, then what are you waiting for?

parts.title: I
parts.markdown:
# Growth

1. Commit this to memory:
> Growth is not the expansion of our bodies, but rather, the expansion of our minds and personalities, over time. We must become better in our thinking, speaking, and how we behave as time passes by. That is growth. Anything that does not grow is *dead*.
2. When you are disrespectful today, tomorrow, and in the next ten(10) years, are you growing?
3. When you keep using foul language, day after day, are you growing?
4. When you did not know something yesterday, and now you have learned it, are you growing?
5. Does the stone change and become better as the years go by?
6. Is the stone living or dead?
7. Are you living when you have become unchanging, like the stone?
8. Am I growing or dying?
> I used to be rude to people. One day, I decided I did not want to live like that anymore. I started being kind and gentle with my words, and now when people meet me they are delighted to speak with me.
9. Has my mind expanded?
> Yesterday, I did not know about growth, and now I do.
10. How do you expand your mind?
11. Has my personality expanded?
> Yesterday, I would pray against my enemies. After studying scriptures, I have learned to pray for them, rather than pray against them. This morning, I prayed for my enemies.
12. Is my personality expanding?
> Weeks ago, I could not stand kids. I will walk right past them like they did not exist. Yesterday, I decided to begin to tolerate them and treat them like they actually matter. Now, I attempt to connect with every child I meet.
13. How do you expand your personality?
14. Can you say that you are neither growing nor dying?
15. If you are not growing, are you dying?
16. If you are either growing or dying, should you spend your time doing things that help you grow, or rather die?
17. Should you listen to songs that do not help you to grow?
18. Do the songs you listen to, help you to grow?
19. Should you watch videos that do not help you to grow?
20. Do the videos you watch, help you to grow?
21. Should you have conversations that do not help you to grow?
22. Do your conversations help you to grow?
23. What are some things that you can start doing now, that will help you to grow?
24. Exercise:
	- Get an exercise book and name it your "Growth Book."
	-  In it, every day, write down the things you have done or learned that have helped you grow that day.
	- At the end of each week, find out if you are growing, or dying.
25. Pray asking God to help you to grow and become what he has called you to be.

parts.title: II
parts.markdown:
# Growth II

1. What are the stages of growth?
2. When you are a baby, do you know anything, or understand anything?
3. Do you know the difference between right and wrong?
4. Are you able to learn?
5. Does the spirit of the Father live in you?
6. When you grow to a stage where you now know the difference between right and wrong, good and bad, are you able to choose between right and wrong?
7. Are you able to learn?
8. Does the spirit of the Father come to live in you?
9. Do you start taking steps with God?
10. Why is every step that you take with God called a spirit victory? 
11. When you take steps with God until you become one with God, do you and the Father have the same will?
12. Do you like the things that the Father likes?
13. Do you dislike the things that the Father also dislikes?
14. Do you and God think, speak, and act alike?
15. What did Christ say about himself and the Father when he reached this stage?
16. Are you now under *grace*?
17. Will you willfully disobey the Father?
18. Do you receive anything that you ask the Father?
19. Why do you receive anything that you ask the Father?
20. When you learn from your teacher, do you set questions for yourself, answer the questions, and then tell yourself that you have passed?
21. How would you know that you and the Father have now become one?
22. Will you have any doubts that you are truly a child of the Father when the Father confirms you himself?
23. Do you want the Father to confirm you, or do you want other humans to confirm you?
24. When your spirit is mature, are you able to ascend into the Heavens without first sleeping?
25. When your spirit is mature, are you able to grow to old age because God needs you around to put the good in you into others, you sleep, and then you ascend into the Heavens
26. Which individuals were translated into Heaven without first sleeping?
27. What happens to the spirit of the Father in you, when you fail to ascend?
28. If a reason must be given on behalf of each individual who fails to ascend, why they failed to ascend, should we do what we can to help each other to grow, or rather, discourage them?
29. What are some things that you can do to help other people to grow, and be able to ascend?
30. Which stage are you in now?
31. How do you get to the next stage?
