poems.title: A Better Deal
poems.author: Immanuel R. Knight
poems.body:
# A Better Deal

Immanuel R. Knight

----------

Another “movement”  
Some grassroots protest?  
More reasons to argue  
One big bipartisan mess

Well I’ll tell ya what,  
A better deal exists  
Are you ready to hear?  
Here, try some of this:

Be good to your neighbor  
Sit down and just talk  
Stop being a stranger  
Say “hi” when you walk

See each other colorblind  
Share some laughs and a smile  
Sit back and be kind  
(Just every once in a while)

Stop screaming over politics  
Want to make real change?  
Empty out your own pockets  
Or is giving too strange?

Drop all those “isms”  
They only tear and divide  
We’ve had one too many schisms  
Those speakers? They’ve lied

Start giving, stop begging  
Cease bickering for more  
Work harder, quit nagging  
Hear the knock at your door

poems.title: A Follower Without Footstep
poems.author: Immanuel R. Knight
poems.body:
# A Follower Without Footstep 

Immanuel R. Knight

----------

Struttin’ down sidewalk  
Cane in hand, skippin’ to believe  
Adventurin’ out the promised land  
Dived deep down devil’s concrete  
He saw a gospel to declare  
Speakin’ God between the lines  
Subtly did those strangers stare  
Beneath sunny, mackerel skies  
Piano staccato echoed out  
Tapped right to heaven’s beat  
Preachin’ love and bein’ kind  
On that cracked and aged street  
A follower without footstep  
Caught against in gait  
Many heard, but most ignored  
It ain’t easy struttin’ straight

poems.title: Born Again
poems.author: Immanuel R. Knight
poems.body:
# Born Again

Immanuel R. Knight

----------

Born again  
Jeroboam  
I saw, I conquered  
They slaughtered the lamb  
I’m trembling, I’m seizing  
There’s no way but believing  
These ravens, they feed me  
Elijah fled, free me  
Once lost without wandering  
Wayward without sauntering  
I met God on his mountain  
He left in a cloud  
Raising his dead son’s shroud  
Once lost without wandering  
Wayward without sauntering  
My footsteps keep pondering  
Wavering  
His water I’m savoring  
Born again

poems.title: Boulevard of Better Dreams
poems.author: Immanuel R. Knight
poems.body:
# Boulevard of Better Dreams

Immanuel R. Knight

----------

Give first, before being told to give  
Love first, before feeling a need to live  
Sway first, without being blown to sway  
Choose first, choose love now and every day

Do you wish to see a newer world?  
Politics pollute, turn heart to pearl  
Travel time, defy the stream  
Dare to live and strive to dream

Howling to many is nowhere to start  
One at a time, so passes the spark  
A little love here, a gift given there  
Ye needn’t feel forced to love and to share

Anger not lest ye fall away  
A gentle word has the strongest say  
Teach a man to fish, yet lend while ye may  
Take brother in arm, hold hatred at bay

It isn’t hard to follow such creed  
When while you want, there are others in need  
The world needn’t force you to do what is right  
By your hand through God, reveal his light

poems.title: Conflict of Ages
poems.author: Immanuel R. Knight
poems.body:
# Conflict of Ages

Immanuel R. Knight

----------

These are difficult times, oh friend  
Gods tears, they’re fallin’, all over again  
A sorrowed soak will nourish our roots  
Though bitter now, we’ll bear sweet fruits

You’ll hear all kinds of evil in news  
Of men turned mad, their hearts abused  
A shade has befallen the human soul  
Our hearts are opened to the tainted toll

Men do not see eye to eye  
They’d rather perceive “I” to “I”  
There is blindness about, all across and through  
Yet this means not you must follow them too

Be called by God through heart inside  
Fear not the shadow, it will subside  
I proclaim an end to the wicked’s reign  
Though there shall be but birthing pain

A bearing to be, Christ returned  
He never left, oh, ye who yearned  
A second coming I proclaim, I call  
Not from sky, but you, from all

Open now thy heart to Christ, his throne  
Beware not this world, you’ll make it home  
Delusion is programmed beneath the veil  
Though God she’s set, she’s free to sail

A gospel of love will replace the future  
When evil is done, so stitched and sutured  
Support thyself on a pedestal of hope  
Give from joy of giving, par anchor too and rope

Believe, oh believe, shadows all will die  
See, oh see, she who owns our sky  
Your spirit is but a dream’s deny  
Your body, this flesh, must ye defy

A conflict of ages within each and all  
A battle inside, our rise, our fall  
Before the dawn there’s always dark  
But remember those stars, how her heavens hark

poems.title: Consider the Good
poems.author: Immanuel R. Knight
poems.body:
# Consider the Good

Immanuel R. Knight

----------

There’s some bad out there, oh traveler  
But never forget the good  
Shadows thrive only in their valley  
Recall that mount, where the son once stood

Wrap not thy head in a cloth of worry  
Give your heart to God  
In not these matters wander or hurry  
Ponder not the wicked, nor evils abroad

Give your thoughts everyday to God  
In love remember, in thanks bequeath  
Perform good acts, of righteous thought  
Love thy neighbor in every deed

Consider the good that others hide  
Evil wants you to think it’s gone  
God’s goodness abounds all the time  
In love and light, do stand upon

Give God your worries, your every need  
Surrender your heart in full  
In the end of forever only God will be  
So good, so great, so wonderful

Just believe in the good  
Shine your heart with hope  
Give greatly and greater if you would  
No need to muse, meander, or mope

poems.title: Do You Wish to Know God?
poems.author: Immanuel R. Knight
poems.body:
# Do You Wish to Know God?

Immanuel R. Knight

----------

Do you wish to know God, oh passerby?  
Well listen up, a testament’s nigh  
Seek as ye will across heaven’s sky  
Before one stumbles in the sinner’s sty

Pass thy bread and butter today  
Into another’s hands, live by this I say  
Daily appointed, oh if ye may  
“Give us thy bread”, give thy bread away

Approach one stranger stuck in need  
Be a hand to teach, many fish do feed  
Care thou’st remember good words and a deed?  
Remember one Samaritan, remember his creed

Spread a word so kind and merry  
Make everyday Christmas, oh do this verily  
Pass thy time partin’ songs that carry  
Dance thy heart clear across heaven’s ferry

Be slow to judge and slower still  
To pass thy heart through gossip’s sill  
Every lie and word spoken so ill  
Why, they bury the heart, bury you they will

Take thy pride and cast it down  
As before the stars, God’s evening gown  
What are we but a dreamer’s drown?  
Become a jester, humble thyself a clown

Pass one another with a gentle stare  
Give not in anger or that prideful glare  
Smile, be brighter, all and everywhere  
One oft entertains angels unawares

Show another, light the way  
Maybe, just maybe, you’ll brighten their day  
Teach of giving, of goodness do say  
For each and all, think of they when ye pray

poems.title: Hourglass
poems.author: Immanuel R. Knight
poems.body:
# Hourglass

Immanuel R. Knight

----------

Make yourself right with God  
As with father and thy neighbor  
Stand chin up upon his sod  
Cease ignoring, and don’t belabor

Face your giants without fear  
We all have somethin’ to answer for  
Somethin’ we’ve done there, or here  
You don’t have to hide anymore

What’s hidden will be revealed  
Every act and deed so done  
Might as well stand chin up now  
Before time left is none

Speak up now, or forever hold your peace  
Talk to God today, not tomorrow  
Give in thanks, and in earnest keep  
Leave no lies left to borrow

Maybe God really just wants to talk  
Have you ever considered that?  
With you always does he walk  
When you cried, by you he sat

Repent not as a worshiper  
But as a friend well in need  
You needn’t be afraid of your tears  
Nor the secrets you’ve tried to keep

God is offering you a shoulder  
Forever extending out his hand  
Talk now, and spill thy heart  
Before the hourglass spills its sand

poems.title: Modernity?
poems.author: Immanuel R. Knight
poems.body:
# Modernity?

Immanuel R. Knight

----------

You won’t find people wavin’ hello to strangers anymore  
They’re too busy textin’, and typin’ galore  
We sure got lots, but not like the ole days  
Confucius and Christ taught good lessons, I’d say  
We’ve fallen far from the well-beaten path  
Stringing along with us insanity’s sash  
Division and quarreling define our world now  
Politics and pastors have taken their vows  
We’d rather seek only after what’s good for us  
Neglecting our neighbors on a cold empty bus  
Who’s got real friends anymore these days?  
Just followers and gossipers, all fakes I’d say  
Sons and fathers denyin’ each other  
What marriage still lasts, “what happened to mother?”  
You can’t paint your picture upon a mound o’ kings  
Where self is lost and the idolater sings  
Family no more, just obeyin’ big brother  
Real charity lost beneath one roof or another  
Boy, we’re sure makin’ some progress!  
Right off that ole ledge to the valley o’ death  
Who cares anymore about them ole ways?  
We’ve covered our ears to the pleadin’ o’ graves

poems.title: Rejoice!
poems.author: Immanuel R. Knight
poems.body:
# Rejoice!

Immanuel R. Knight

----------

Rejoice from your heart  
Singing forward a better day  
Be thankful in tomorrow  
Share when you pray

Rejoice from your love  
Dreaming forth what is bright  
Be giving in today  
Always doing what is right

Rejoice from your soul  
Spelling out a new dawn  
Be gracious to your neighbor  
To each tree, bird, and fawn

Rejoice from your spirit  
Calling towards a good dream  
Be always with hope  
Row gently God’s stream

Rejoice when you sing  
Rejoice when you dream  
Rejoice in all goodness  
And in every good thing

poems.title: Sand Castles
poems.author: Immanuel R. Knight
poems.body:
# Sand Castles

Immanuel R. Knight

----------

No parcel of land here is worth disputing  
No brick nor bundle worth the feuding  
Like sand in water it all shall pass  
Only love will live and forever last

What children are we to fight and bicker  
Must we beckon our mother all the quicker?  
The shadow of the valley is dark indeed  
Though I tell you now, our mother will heed

Go ahead and build your castles of sand  
Fight and feud over strips of land  
But at the end her waves will wash  
Just sit and see, wait and watch

poems.title: The Last Evangelist
poems.author: Immanuel R. Knight
poems.body:
# The Last Evangelist

Immanuel R. Knight

----------

Witness to the once born  
From wilderness to Sinai  
Well attended and received  
Hybrid affairs drawn not in heaven  
Unholy youth nearly cut short  
Rode a bike across asphalt unforgiving  
Crashing lights as they prepared their way  
Perceiving thoughts like paper  
Two followed behind as he pursued  
A false prophet and beast to bear  
Each sneering just far enough in the dark  
Cheered on by flickering amber  
One might’ve mistaken evil for a hipster  
A new age for old idols  
He warned his brother; was it too late?  
Darkened streets and a race home  
The good book on a poor man’s shelf  
One sword against their rise  
For the first and final time  
The last evangelist preached

poems.title: The Shadow Out of Eden
poems.author: Immanuel R. Knight
poems.body:
# The Shadow Out of Eden

Immanuel R. Knight

----------

Woman’s beauty is in her tenderness  
That nurturing wisdom only a mother may know  
A body is naught but a poor shadow, one falsehood promised  
Pleasures taken therein are fleeting nothings, and will pass  
At time’s end all beauty of flesh shall be left unremembered  
A woman is made beautiful not by her shadow, but through her heart  
By her light, the real love of a mother  
Through which she is fulfilled

But for the small price of abandoning her heart, the fruit of compassion  
For sacrificing them unto the alters of Moloch and Belial  
Thence indulging in all her tongue may salivate after  
With neither care nor burden put upon her bosom  
But what then, in her elder years?

No child to declare _“that was my mother, and I loved her”_  
No husband to promise _“I will cherish her always in my heart”_  
No witness to attest _“she lived righteously, and was good”_  
No judge to decree _“she is blameless before all her days”_  
What then of her?  
What then of true beauty forgone?

Be tied not up in your bundles and bodies  
For these all shall wither and pass  
Only one thing is truly eternal  
And that’s real love, which will forever last

poems.title: The Venetian Man
poems.author: Immanuel R. Knight
poems.body:
# The Venetian Man

Immanuel R. Knight

----------

A golden “prophet”  
Swooning generations  
Words to impress  
Stepping down the trodden  
Erecting idols for Aaron  
A Canaanite’s dream  
Moloch’s bequest  
The second between three  
Delivering miracles to the lacking  
Raining fire from heaven  
By slight of false sermons  
And the aeon of dying dreams  
Too beautiful to be beheld  
Followed not by none  
Believed and betrothed  
To a bride most unbecoming  
A memory beneath moonlight  
One’s song between whistles  
Drawing forth the unassuming  
By path paved gold in thistles  
Few will recognize those days  
No drummer will commemorate in drumming  
A silent though assured arrival  
The Venetian Man forthcoming

poems.title: The Way
poems.author: Immanuel R. Knight
poems.body:
# The Way

Immanuel R. Knight

----------

Don’t give up, traveler  
No great thing is ever easy  
I know you’re tired on that narrow path  
Just keep trekking forward, believing  
Alone you tread not, know this  
Though others may laugh at your gait  
Keep going, keep moving, and always persist  
You are chosen, quite destined, by fate  
It’s never easy alone in the wind  
But I tell you there are treasures awaiting  
You must keep moving, whether walking or crawling  
No star is worth its weight in stating  
Never give up in dead of night  
Staring at ceiling alone  
Remember he who hath given you life  
While others gaze blindly at phone  
Each is allotted their portion  
There is treasure hidden in heartache  
Beware the world’s moral extortion  
Your journey is yours to make

poems.title: To Protest a Generation
poems.author: Immanuel R. Knight
poems.body:
# To Protest a Generation

Immanuel R. Knight

----------

What is it, to protest a generation?  
By what feats are miracles accomplished?  
I see not the sunny-side of that promised land  
Nor the penance of a people purloined  
Institutions inspiring the inane  
Creeds conspiring conflict  
All testament to the tacit tyranny  

Always shall there be retribution for the unrighteous?  
And what of that one voice crying out in the crowd:  
“What you do is wrong, this is not right!  
“Sweet Justice, I beg of you, shine your light upon them!”  
Still they shout, “be silent!” rejecting, and renouncing  
Gnawing the leaven of a more spoiled yeast:  

A Mother who would slaughter the fruit of her womb  
Not once, not twice, but thrice, and more  
Her body no longer temple for love, and goodness  
But shrine to the unborn, the unmourned  
A most twisted pleasure around Hell’s pyre  
Where Moloch growls, aching in his hunger  

A father who would forgo his sons and daughters  
Weeping not for the seed of his heart left to wilt  
Beneath heat of a sky leaking no rain  
Dreamt a drought for the weary  
Whose tales of whimsy wane  

People perplexed by politics, pettiest affairs  
Too busy to notice their future slipping away  
A posterity drowned in neglect’s mire  
Their cries muffled by a Causus Belli  
Twenty-one guns for ninety-nine theses  

Children caught up staring down  
Idolizing the arrogant, in apathy  
Drenched in likes, subscriptions to sin  
Their kinship foretold insanity  

And when a man unbecoming approaches them to declare:  
“This is wrong, your ways are wrong! Justice, I say!”  
They will argue politics and privilege,  
Subjectivity and relativity, the freedom of the unhinged  
But I ask, is any one truly free when bound by flesh  
Left to rot at the end of an eighty-year’s decay?  
And they will beat him, and deride him  
Casting him from their doorsteps, laughing  

Yet when they with the eyes of an angel comes to greet them  
Preaching the only gospel their hearts have ever known  
They will cheer and smile, cry out and weep with joy  
“Our savior has come!”, the many will scream in rapture  
Like young girls giddy over a handsome boy  

And how then shall they be taken up by streamers!  
Bright lights and music, dance and revelry  
From a pen whose door had been left open  
Stammering out into their hearts’ wilderness  
Beckoned by the angel-eyed, the heaven-tongued  
And once rampaged and ravaged to all their delight  
Each mask will come off, every light will dim  
Left naked in the dark

poems.title: Tongues Like Lions
poems.author: Immanuel R. Knight
poems.body:
# Tongues Like Lions

Immanuel R. Knight

----------

Be wary of the miser’s ministry  
Mammon’s injunction leads duly to misery  
What wolves prowl pretending to be priests?  
Preachers partaking in the pharisees’ feasts  
No miracle is ever made manifest by man  
Whose wine when touched turns spirits to sand  
Be wary of doomsday dreamers  
Who wave their hands and prophesy all day  
They speak and spout with authority of clay  
Whose ministries rely on death not redemption  
Whose pockets are lined with devil’s ademption  
Hardened hearts masked by soft words  
Whispered through the path of two-thirds  
With tongues like lions spewing forward bequest  
Zeal of Balaam, Beelzebul’s zest

poems.title: What To Say?
poems.author: Immanuel R. Knight
poems.body:
# What To Say?

Immanuel R. Knight

----------

Don’t know what to say?  
Here, I’ll offer some words  
Take them, if you may  
For what they are, and what they’re worth

Offer words of kindness  
For those who are lost and alone  
Give them a reason to smile  
Give their words a home

Offer thoughts of hope  
To those who pass you by  
Perhaps a wayward stranger  
Who lets their silence cry

Offer parables of faith  
To those with ears to hear  
Teach them the value of trust  
To hold God ever dear

poems.title: With Me Always
poems.author: Immanuel R. Knight
poems.body:
# With Me Always

Immanuel R. Knight

----------

Who has need for a bible, or book  
If possessed is their heart by the holy spirit?  
Who has need for words and pages  
Which may be torn and withered  
If possessed are their eyes by sight?  
Who has need for preachers and prophets  
Whose voices may croak and falter  
If possessed are their ears by song?

With me always is my bible  
That of the heart  
With me always is my beloved  
Who dwells therein  
With me always is my God  
Whose words are wind and water

Possess my heart in love, oh beloved  
And never shall a day pass  
That I know not your gospel  
And never shall a night fall  
That I know not your love

For what is the quickest way to you  
Oh beloved?  
What is the quickest path to your heart  
But by love?

poems.title: Would You Believe It?
poems.author: Immanuel R. Knight
poems.body:
# Would You Believe It?

Immanuel R. Knight

----------

Someone came for you, someone loves you so much  
All they want to do is give your heart a touch  
For what’s the name of the game in love?  
To sacrifice all for your one beloved

You may sin and you may stray  
You might just turn and walk away  
But all you have to do is in her love believe  
Someone gave for you, gave it all, you see?

You are loved, a shining star  
The praise of angels from afar  
You the sinner, you the thief  
You the king of every fief

Would you believe it? She loves you so much  
She sent her son to give you a touch  
Like mother, like child, all there the same  
For you she brought, for you she came

I’m but a mouthpiece for this truest love’s say  
You may not know her, but she thinks of you every day  
You the forgotten, even you the remembered  
She came for you on a day past December

Whether surrounded by friends or all alone on a bench  
She’ll hold you ever close, she’ll tear down every fence  
Now you may ask, “what must I need?”  
I say for all, and to all:

Believe

poems.title: Your Best
poems.author: Immanuel R. Knight
poems.body:
# Your Best

Immanuel R. Knight

----------

Do always your best unto others  
Treating them warmly with smiles  
Be kind to sisters and brothers  
Lifting spirits evermore, all the whiles

Do always your best unto neighbors  
You can bring down heaven to here  
Why wait for the appearance of saviors  
When you hold Christ’s key ever near?

Do always your best unto strangers  
You never know who you might find  
An angel on their way to some mangers  
Following stars, leaving all else behind

Do always your best unto each  
May no evil pass through thy lips  
Be wary of the truth ye teach  
And the cup adversity sips

poems.title: ♚ Life’s Petty King$ ♛
poems.author: Immanuel R. Knight
poems.body:
# ♚ Life’s Petty King$ ♛

Immanuel R. Knight

----------

Humpty Dumpty sat on a wall  
Humpty Dumpty ruled before all  
A dollar sign here, a dollar sign there  
Lives lived by a dead-president’s stare

Whilst we tweeted and twittered each day  
Our lives so fleeted and flittered away  
As eyes lay glued to screen-bright attractions  
Hearts sank deep through dead-moral distractions

Paper and plastic, plastic and paper  
These things the kings, the treasures we savor  
Humpty Dumpties in everyone’s pockets  
Sucking our souls straight out of their sockets

Gold and silver, silver and gold  
“Such pretty rings!” Our hearts we’ve sold  
Life’s petty kings, or so we’re told  
From pink and young until grey and old

Humpty Dumpty sat on a wall  
But we were the ones who took a great fall  
Whilst he sat and laughed on high  
The kings our wallets, our hearts sucked dry

poems.title: Daughter of Eve
poems.author: Lori McCray
poems.body:
# Daughter of Eve

Lori McCray

----------

Daughter of Eve, ever curious, your need to know can lead you into shadowland.  
Stay in the Light, and what you need to know and do will be revealed to you.  
Darkness, so long your familiar, has lost its power to sway you.  
No longer innocent, yet wise, you have earned your right to see what you see, and say so.

poems.title: Follow the Light
poems.author: Lori McCray
poems.body:
# Follow the Light

Lori McCray

----------

Selflessness is a criterion for sainthood.  
Patience. Purity. Gentleness. A tongue which never curses.  

Honesty. Compassion. A Love which never falters.  
Peacefulness. Sincerity. Trustworthy, Respectability. Long-suffering. Joy. Wisdom. Gratitude. Mercy. Detachment from all agendas, except for God’s.  
Serenity. Kindness. Cheerfulness. Helpfulness. Intelligence. Beneficence.  

Openness. Awareness, and to end where we began, Unselfishness.  
A saint is a person at the pinnacle of perfection.  
Guided by Grace.  
Full of God’s Glory.  
Divinely human, capable of transgression but always choosing the most elegant response.  

A saint leaves a trail on the high road. Shines a Light ~ hoping that you will follow.

poems.title: Higher Ground
poems.author: Lori McCray
poems.body:
# Higher Ground

Lori McCray

----------

The meek shall inherit the earth, while the rich call them idiots.  
The humble, blessed with humility, are a peculiar people.  
Refusing to live in fear, they follow the Light of Truth, where ever it might lead them.  
Questioning, yet paradoxically, unquestioning.  
Thoughtful, but able to suspend thinking.  
Open, yet rarely revealing the sacred sanctum.  
Generous, yet withholding the keys to the inner storehouse until the friend proves trustworthy.

Balanced and sure-footed in darkness.  
Buoyant in flooding waters.  
Hopeful even in disaster, the meek wait patiently for Love to uphold, uplift, to carry them, as promised, to higher ground.

poems.title: Let Love Lift You Up
poems.author: Lori McCray
poems.body:
# Let Love Lift You Up

Lori McCray

----------

There’s a peace which cannot be worded, in the hermitage of your heart.  
Love meets you there, tucks you tenderly beneath her wings, and carries you gently over the pass you cannot walk alone.

You can trust Love with your life.  
Drop all your worries. Let Love lift you up.  
Feel the power in those mighty wings.  
Whatever you thought to be hopelessly broken, know that Love can make it whole.

poems.title: Live in Your Heart and Not Your Head
poems.author: Lori McCray
poems.body:
# Live in Your Heart and Not Your Head

Lori McCray

----------

At some point, you must release the past.  
Every bad decision, marks missed, royal screw ups, forgive and go on, having learned the pivotal lesson, newly aware, you can now see it coming. 
Dragging it all behind you is a waste of energy.  
Being free releases creativity, Speaking truth clears confusion.  
The world is full of cloudy mirrors.  
Keep yours clean. Have a smile for everyone.  
It’s really that simple.

poems.title: Living in the Sacred Heart
poems.author: Lori McCray
poems.body:
# Living in the Sacred Heart

Lori McCray

----------

Living in the Sacred Heart, there is no duality, for Love has no opposite.  
There, in the sacred center of your soul, in that holy silence, lies the Source of all Being, the Source who Loved you into Being, so you could be Love.  

In that peaceful, prayerful chamber, where you have retreated to find rest and rejuvenation, there is no judgment and no lack.  
Let that unity be your prayer, your life that powerful unity, and your Love a steady witness and willing servant to the purity of Peace.

poems.title: Moral Compass
poems.author: Lori McCray
poems.body:
# Moral Compass

Lori McCray

----------

Don’t let your heart be troubled.  
Don’t let your thoughts run wild.  
Do not be afraid.  
Be present.  
Love free of conditions.  
Be gentle with your words.  
Sit silently and see.  
Listen carefully.  
Act on your visions.  
Be willing to know more.  
Turn away from falsehood.  
Be scrupulously honest. 
Drop duality.  
Stay open, ready to receive.  
Be flexible, yet grounded.  
Only the perfect should offer advice.  
Let your soul be transparent.  
Don’t abandon your beliefs.  
Be cheerful. Thankful. Approachable. Invite miracles. Welcome whimsy.  
See trouble in advance. Avoid it.  
Don’t fall prey to hubris. Admit your mistakes.  
Praise the Good where you find it.  
Seek Beauty. Love Nature. Protect the Innocent. Feed the hungry.  
Give what you can, when you can, wherever you can.  
Be fruitful. Peaceful. Creative. Compassionate.  
Believe in Abundance.  
Share your wealth.

poems.title: No One Can Steal Your Treasure
poems.author: Lori McCray
poems.body:
# No One Can Steal Your Treasure

Lori McCray

----------

Shine a light.  
Hope against darkness.  
In the shadow cast by pain, wait patiently for healing.  
Wisdom comes from suffering, if you absorb the alchemy and honor it.  
Use your gold, which you have earned, as a rite of passage.  
Your journey will feel lighter now, in this new country called ‘Surrender’.  
Accept the authority to fashion your own map and trust your own direction.  
No need to bury your treasure.  
It’s yours, forever.

poems.title: Pastorale
poems.author: Lori McCray
poems.body:
# Pastorale

Lori McCray

----------
Sheep may safely graze, but first, quite a few will be eaten.

poems.title: Radical Grace
poems.author: Lori McCray
poems.body:
# Radical Grace

Lori McCray

----------

My life is an undeserved mercy.  
Since I threw it away, gave up on it, rejected the gift ~ yet here I am, living it.  
Loving it at last.  
I was not given up on.  
I’m here because I still have work to do.

Dear Lord, before I die, I want to see my Self in your Beauty.  
Make my soul holy.  
Help me follow you more closely in the shadowlands, until your vision becomes my own.  
Show me the way to embrace paradox and keep me patient before Mystery.

Wisdom sees all things at once, without separation or division.  
Teach me the meaning of ‘Oneness’, oh ‘Perfecter of our faith’.  
Strengthen my desire to hold the tension of the opposites.  
Let me say Yes to everyone and everything, yet keep a watchful eye on evil.  
Deliver me, oh Lord, from the brambles which would entangle me and make my path steady, to the place where you are waiting, always ready to receive and bless.  
Sanctify my love, so merely human and filled with weakness.  
Elevate my offering and out of my humility, grant me your grace.  
I promise not to keep it for myself.

poems.title: Soften Your Heart, That Love May Grow
poems.author: Lori McCray
poems.body:
# Soften Your Heart, That Love May Grow

Lori McCray

----------

If the heart has grown hard  
nothing new can be planted.

You cannot dig your bulbs  
when the earth is frozen.

Soften your heart, that Love may grow.  
Plant mercy in the furrows of your soul.  
Shoots of tenderness will blossom.

poems.title: Translucence
poems.author: Lori McCray
poems.body:
# Translucence

Lori McCray

----------

I pray my name is written in the Book of Life.  
I flirted with death so many years, he thought he had me.  
Spilled my own blood, to make certain I was living.  
Life was a class I’d slept through, and when I woke up, I was clueless and confused.  
I watched other people to learn their ways, not being formally educated, vulnerable to ridicule.

Outsiders know they’re missing something, but no one tells them what it is.  
It’s like a joke you don’t get, but everyone is laughing.  
Laugh or be found stupid, of course you laugh.  
Maybe We the People don’t want to be laughed at, though most everyone is laughing at us.  
We don’t want to think for ourselves, so we see what the news has to say, and give them the power to feed us.  
Most of it’s not nourishing. People enjoy drama and mayhem.  
Soft news sells nothing, puts people to sleep.  
I no longer feel guilty for not watching.  
I don’t go slow to see the car wreck, and am trying hard not to gossip.  
I’m staying in my own business.  
Who am I, to poke around in yours?

Life seems much simpler now.  
Kinder. Honest. Peaceful.  
I don’t do things to *make* me happy (but if doing them makes me unhappy, why keep doing them?), but make decisions based on merit.  
If it’s worth doing, if there’s benefit, I do it and I am happy (if I fail to do it well and it seems worth it, I try harder, work longer, get advice and do it better.  
If I see that I’m not suited, no matter the effort, I turn it over to those more capable. No shame. No judgment).  
When I leave this life, I want to be translucent.  
I want to Love so well, so deeply, there simply isn’t another choice.

poems.title: Tunnel of Love
poems.author: Lori McCray
poems.body:
# Tunnel of Love

Lori McCray

----------

There is a passageway, from this world to the next.  
Its name is Love.

poems.title: What’s in a name?
poems.author: Lori McCray
poems.body:
# What’s in a name?

Lori McCray

----------

It seems to me, a type of dis-ease, the way we classify and categorize, give genus and species, learn Latin.  
We mount our gorgeous butterflies on poster board and speculate on the dead.  
Leave the butterflies feeding in the field.  
Enjoy their beauty, protect their freedom.  
The joy of nature is not in naming but in Loving.

A tiny flower appears on a rotting log.  
I may love it profoundly, and never know its name.  
The advancement of science is marvelous, but not at the expense of losing our deep reverence and respect for all sentient beings.  
We must learn to think with the heart, to see our world through the eyes of Love, and to honor our connection with All That Is.  
Our lives depend on it.

poems.title: Distracted By Distance
poems.author: Mike Essig
poems.body:
# Distracted By Distance

Mike Essig

----------

_See a World in a Grain of Sand…_

Now is the nose that  
floats unnoticed on a face  
too close to see clearly.

Distracted by distance,  
we overlook the near.  
We pass over places  
we never fully inhabit  
on our way to places  
we never quite arrive.

So hard to focus  
on the world at hand.

How to really be and see?

Eat slowly. Chew well.  
Stll your mind and listen.  
The sound of crickets  
you forget to hear  
is life singing to you  
as it glides off.

Stop gazing at forests.  
Consider trees, please.

There is magic in noticing  
what the days have to say.

Make the present shine  
before it slips away.

poems.title: Intentions
poems.author: Mike Essig
poems.body:
# Intentions

Mike Essig

----------

Years ago I  
was ambitious,  
but nothing  
happened and  
I forgot to try.

A thousand poems  
written in blood.  
Only the Void  
reads them now.

Plan your life;  
hear God laugh.

You can’t give  
the wind orders.

It blows whichever  
way it wants to go.

poems.title: Thanksgiving
poems.author: Mike Essig
poems.body:
# Thanksgiving

Mike Essig

----------

Gratitude is Magick,  
a spell cast against  
despair and doom.

It makes whatever  
you have enough.

Miracles abound  
in even the  
least of lives.

Cherish the time  
that is given you;  
it will run out  
before you know it.

Be thankful to sit  
and laugh among  
those you love.

It might be otherwise.

Know that each  
breath is a gift.

Welcome the  
uncertain future.

Time destroys  
all that lives.

Material things  
decay and fall away.

Spirit is life.

Open your heart  
to what remains.

Take what you have  
and make something new.

Do not fear death;  
it is only the  
beginning of wonder.

Live like today  
is the last day.

**_Practice resurrection._**

poems.title: Joy Of Africa
poems.author: Omar Talib
poems.body:
# Joy Of Africa

Omar Talib

----------

Sing for me your ancient tune  
From bark of tree to desert dune  
Set my mind and eyes ablaze  
Walk me through primeval days

What distant force, what heartfelt hand  
Combine to make your promised land  
Africa hot, Africa cool  
From mighty desert to ocean pool

Roughened roads to glistening glades,  
Stark black rock to covered caves  
Magnificent mountain, cobalt creeks  
Brittle bedrock, snow capped peaks

Leopard pounds the drum in your heart  
Lion steals his strength from craft  
Cheetah channels all her might  
Spurt of speed and out of sight

Share your wonder with my heart  
Thundering falls, kingfishers dart  
Shed your rainbow and etch my eye  
My soul, my spirit is on a high.

poems.title: Sorrow Of Africa
poems.author: Omar Talib
poems.body:
# Sorrow Of Africa

Omar Talib

----------

I will see the children cry  
I will see their Papa starve and die  
I will see their Mama trying to try  
I will see all this and sigh.

I will drive by this everyday  
I will think to myself, there is a way  
I will go to my home, a world away  
Sit by my fire with Mozart to play

I will see the children toil  
I will see mama dig the soil  
I will see Papa ‘neath his cross  
His legacy and life, a loss

I will leave at dusk to fly away  
Looking forward to another day  
I will meet my friends and have a drink  
Pink Champagne, who has to blink?

I will see mama under the sun  
Her bleeding fingers hope the day is done  
I will see mama under the moon  
Tears of resolve forestall their doom

I will see my glass, bubbling pink  
I scold myself for how much I think  
“Relax” I say, “It’s not your fault”  
Sip away and worry naught.

I will leave at dawn to fly back home  
I will see the children all alone  
I will see mama ‘neath her cross  
Her Legacy and life, a loss

I see my face in a mirror  
What stares me back is a horror  
My life, my wealth, my sheer pleasure  
Africa, her children waste in squalor.
